content.description: A corner crack just right of an ow crack. Starts 3’s, 4’s for a little while, back to 3’s then a 2.
content.location: Just right of flicking the bean, left of the chimney route with the fixed angle.

content.description: Not sure this route gets any traffic, although it's a great moderate that should clean up nicely. Tossed down a few death blocks, but there is still loose stuff at the top. Fun jamming all the way up.
content.location: The crack on the left side of the "Nice n' Tight" pillar.

content.description: Be warned, the rock quality on this route is poor when compared to other splitters at IC. Start by carefully mantling onto a choss block covered in choss. Enter a detached block double crack system climbing hands or thin hands or both. Place some cams in hollow sounding rock. Encounter some cupped hands calcite plagued by hollow rock on the left and right side of this crack. This is where you start cursing the guidebook for saying "Optional 4". While there were many places that other sized cams looked good, it was really only the fist+ size cracks that didn't have hollow rock on either side with the exception of a few spots. Make some more moves and then enter a fists/ow crack that brings you up under the roof. Curse the guide book again as you place a thin hands sized cam behind this #5 sized crack. Pull some amazing OW roof moves and wonder how this thing is only 5.10. At this point I broke a foothold off and it landed right on my belayers shoulder, luckily it was only around the size of a clementine, but it still did enough damage to cut our trip short. This route could use some cleaning and climbers should tread lightly. I would not climb this again and I would not recommend it to anyone who likes their belayer. The roof on this route would make it worth doing if not for the choss. One star.
content.protection: hand sizes and 3x #4 to protect in places where there is no hollow rock.
content.location: This route is located at the top of the trail to the right. You can identify it by the chossy red block at the base and a couple of detached blocks making a twin crack start. Looking up the crack you will see some calcite inside the crack reminding you to tape up. This thing has little calcite thorns in it, be warned. The route is capped by a burly lookin roof/bulge that block the site of the anchor.

climbs.name: Trouser Snake
climbs.fa: FA. Kingsbury, Reinsel, Bowman.  FFA. Bowman, Kingsbury

content.description: Sandy and loose face climbing lead to a steep finish.  A real creek classic!
content.protection: a fixed spike and two bolts, single bolt anchor
content.location: at the campsite in the back of the Technicolor/ gash drainage

content.description:
Sababa is a break off extension of Flicking The Bean. Climb the double hand cracks of that route, then set some small gear in a thin crack where FTB begins its leftward traverse. Make a face traverse on obvious positive crimps to gain the crack out right. Climb hands that drops down before a bulging roof, then climb sustain tight hand and ring locks to the anchor.

A mega pitch that protects well and is worth the effort.
content.protection: Many hand size for the start of flicking the bean. I placed a grey and purple metals before the face traverse. Then many 0.4, 0.5, 0.75 and  #1 BD cams for the top. Alpine draws are good to mitigate rope drag. New 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Start on Flicking The Bean. Plaque for Sababa at the base

content.description: A nice, clean tight-knee OW in a shallow right-facing dihedral. Starts butterflies, mainly tight hand-fist stacks. Ends on large ledge.
content.protection: (1x)old #4 BD, (4x) new #5 BD, (1x) #6 BD, chain/cold shut anchor.
content.location: From where the trail meets the wall, head right along the north-facing aspect of the wall for a couple of hundred feet. This is over by the Unnamed/Unknown hands/big hands routes listed in the guide. It is a ways left of the Gash itself though. There's a plaque.

content.description: This route is identified by and splitter hands to tips crack on the main wall with a pillar to the left that creates an offwidth.  The splitter gradually gets smaller as the offwidth gets wider.
content.protection: Hands to tips, one of each size should suffice.  Two bolt anchor.

content.description: boulder up a jutting flake (far to the right of hot dogs) to a left-facing corner
content.protection: multiple cams from .5 camalot to #3 and 1 # 5

content.location: far left side, possible the first climb

content.description: A sustained steep thin hands to big hands corner with an OW flared squeeze at the top protected with a bolt
content.protection: One draw, two bd 4's one or two 4 friend or bd3.5's,three or four bd 3's and a one and a 2
content.location:
Way right almost to the over the hill crag

Super shady

content.description: About 200 yds left of Bud's, start up some large blocks, angle right. You will be below a dihedral & a crack. Take the overlapping crack on the face, not the choss-filled dihedral. About 50 feet up it is possible to step left if you are tall, into a #4 crack, choose your own adventure, or stay right for a slightly more sustained outing. The 2 cracks converge a bit higher & traverse left on a hand traverse reminiscent of Way Rambo. Continue up the arcing crack to the anchors. 35m
content.protection: 1 #4 cam, 1 #3 cam, 4 #2 cams, 2 #1 cams, 2 #.75 cams, 2  #.5 cams, for the right hand crack. More #4 & #3 cams for the left crack
content.location: Walk 200 yds left of Bud's route, passing a large dihedral with an unclimbed offwidth in it. Flicking the Bean is on the face left of the dihedral

climbs.name: Dusty Pussy
climbs.fa: Will Foster FA, Second Anika Bach and John Fitzpatrick

content.description: Climb the glorious 1-3's in a lichen corner. The angle eases and then climb up and over a flake. Enter a flare with 3-4's at the back. Work your way up into the Dusty Pussy and then re-emerge by working your way on 3's over the roof to a ledge and the anchors.
content.protection: 1 ea .4-.75, couple 1-2's, lots of 3's, couple 4's, some wide gear. 70m Rope
content.location: This route is on the same ledge as Mongrel and goes up the right facing corner

content.description:
I felt it was hateful. Good size to get good at though

Start in a big left facing corner formed by the wall and a large detached pillar. Head up the crack until you get below a fixed pin. Getting into the chimney here is the crux. I thought it was pretty damn hard, but I also suck at OWing. Once you are "comfortably" into the chimney work your way up and protect with a finger crack in the back. Progress upwards to the top of the pillar.

Belayer might want to belay a little way from the base. Watch out for loose rock
Semi wandering crack. Watch out for choss! Belayer should really wear a helmet
content.location: a little left of a MASSIVE overhanging left facing corner, cannot miss this thing

content.description: Climb the left of two splitter crack until it is possible to switch to the right crack.  Follow this for a couple body lengths and then move back left to the anchor.  It is also possible to just climb the left crack at about 5.11.
content.protection: 2 each .75 to #3, a .4 or .5 might be useful depending on how far you climb up the left crack.  Anchor is two bolt with quick links but some chain would be a nice addition.
content.location: Right of "Jutting Flake" and about 20' left of "Nice n' Tight".

content.description: sandy with a blocky start, go fingers to hands
content.location: this is a route just on the north side of cliff, start on some blocks.

content.description:
Very aesthetic route

Start on chossy bouldery moves into a left facing corner. Good jams until the crack widens to fist and then OW. Either layback it 7-8 ft until you can get a good foot on the arête and good handjams again, or OW it. Laybacking it would probably be a bit scary on lead, and might make a ledge fall possible. Go up until you can chimney it, miraculously enough. Rest and think out the rest

OWing it probably makes it more 5.11 than 5.11-

Anchors need chains
This route climbs a right facing corner that starts as fingers and widens to hands.  Watch out for loose rock at the horizontal ledge just before the anchor.
content.protection: Fingers to hands.  Two bolt anchor at the top that could use some new webbing.
